Mission accomplished and Trumps farcical demand to land on the moon by 2024 may have actually caused this to occur sooner than it might have otherwise. Let's go back into time to the Bush Administration and the Constellation program, and the Ares I and Ares V heavy Rocket. The Ares I had a test launch in 2008 that was successful, then Ares I-X , this Rocket was based on the solid booster for the Space Schuttle and Orion crew module that was capable of crew adjustments of 2 through 6.
The Ares I-X was flight tested successfully in 2009 on a minimal budget , NASA asked for a budget increase to further develope Ares I and Ares V , which the Obama administration canceled due to politics.
Ares V would have lifted the Altair Lunar Lander into Space and Ares I the Crew Module along with the earth escape stage, the Orion and Altair would have linked up low earth orbit and onto the moon.

Now SlS no question is as big or bigger then the Saturn V, however, as big as SlS is it will do the exact same job Ares I would have done, just lift the Orion Crew Module and the Earth Escape stage .
It will then hook up with the Star Ship / lunar lander.
And Latter another project the Gateway baby space gas station and a starship lunar lander.

Cost plus contracts go over budget because both the government and the contractors use lower cost to sell what they already know will be twice or thrice the cost. A more realistic approach would be giving congress the actual price, which they already know fairly well. A good example for this is the B21 raider. The Airforce and Northrop leaned on B2 program to give congress sticker shock, but once congress sucked it up and paid up, Northrop is below budget ahead of schedule and ultimately saving the Government/tax payers money by not having unnecessary renegotiations. Plus Congress can buy a lot more bombers now.

For those who say that SLS is somehow "stupid" and should be cancelled:
The REAL purpose for SLS is to get NASA a heavy lift rocket they've been wanting for ages, with the lowest amount of engineering required - as it was thought "for cheap". Although it turned out to be expensive, most of these costs have been recurrent ones - engineer salaries, factory maintenance, etc. If most of your yearly budget for a project are costs you have to pay every year, it baloons up. Just a simple example:
You need to produce something for 60 dollars and you need to spend 80$ per X time for food, rent, etc.
If your boss gives you 100$ per X, you will spend a total of 300$ before the project is complete, but if he gives you 140$ per X then you only spend the 140$. Although it may seem counter-intuitive, sometimes the cheapest way to get something done is to give the one doing it more money.

It is very satisfying to see references to Aerojet.  Dr. Theodore von Karman was my Godfather and was a founder of JPL and Aerojet.  My father worked at the Aerojet Azusa plant and my mother worked on Lee Edison’s biography, “The Wind and Beyond”.  Dr Von Karman had such an impact on the fields of Aerodynamics and Astronomics that he received the first National Medal of Science from President Kennedy in 1963.  The divider between the earth and space is referred to as The Karman Line.  We used to visit him at his home in Pasadena, CA when I was just a young space enthusiast.  He passed when I was eleven and remember his funeral service and seeing many of the giants of the world of jet propulsion.  Again, thanks for bringing back a lot of good memories.

The thing I still find most amazing is, well, the Saturn V used literally visible magnets as it's memory for the guidance system programming. This memory was a wire grid sewn BY HAND with iron rings as memory bits. That is still being compared to modern completely digital guidance systems.

He has a tendency to make outlandish claims about what he and his teams are possible of delivering.  They literally sound like these impossible goals, right?  But you gotta remember, this is exactly how they built Tesla.  At this stage in the game, Tesla has HUGE momentum behind.  And they will deliver exactly what Elon has been saying they will deliver for the past 10 years now.  The market is ONLY just starting to be convinced of that.  It's all starting to take off.  Pun intended.  If the success of Tesla is any indication for what the future of Starship will be, well, then I'm convinced I'll see people land on Mars in my lifetime.  I'm 45 now.  I think it will happen in the next 10 years for sure. As for Artemis, it's absolutely awesome, that NASA is building it.  I hope it succeeds.  But I'm pretty sure when SpaceX proves it's success with Starship, It will probably KILL the Artemis SLS.  Then every commercial operation will attempt to recreate what SpaceX does to get in the game.  It's a new Space Race, guys.  Commercially built reusable launch systems are the future.

Tim, you did it, I found an article on the cancellation of the SLS.

Addressing the title question: You said "You couldn't come up with two more opposite vehicles with two more drastically different engineering philosophies." That, in itself, is an excellent reason for continuing the SLS: diverse, redundant abilities. The world should not put all its space-travel eggs into one basket. Having Soyuz and the Space Shuttles was better than Soyuz alone. Likewise, since we are a race of fallen sinners who cannot be relied upon to always act honorably, no nation, for its own security, should put all its space-faring eggs into one basket.
You have pointed out how it is that private enterprise can be superior to government in developing our capabilities. Competition between corporate entities will enhance even that, and I am all in favor of it. Political factors will always make government less efficient than private corporations and eleemosynary organizations at producing products or services. From the early sixties, I have thought the government erred in not having corporate partners in developing our space program. Such partnerships would lead to new products, technologies, etc. for general consumption that would generate profit for corporate partners and NASA alike. NASA's profits would reduce revenue dependency upon a fickle Congress and burdened taxpayers.

Until humanity becomes a race of angels, we should not neglect, as a nation, to maintain a vigorous space program. SLS should continue until we have a better, more efficient system to replace it. We must be careful when comparing Starship operating costs with anything. Have two things in mind:
- Starship does not exist yet, SpaceX is still learning to weld stainless steel, for crying out loud, something that is not, pardon the pun, rocket science.
- Remember the projected operating costs of another mostly reusable system, Space Shuttle (that is, what was left of much better thought through original STS) to the actual costs - they differ by factor of abut ten. Let this be a warning to all wild optimists out there.
While "cost plus" culture certainly contributed to the wildly escalating Shuttle costs, that's not the whole story. In their initial enthusiasm, people tend to gloss over millions of "tiny" problems that will pop up, all of which can be solved, but as cost.

An idea of using Starship as a lunar lander is really ... strange. With its huge dry mass it will require a large number or refuelings , some in Lunar orbit, which means prepositioning the tankers there (which need to be launched and also refueled etc). This would perhaps make sense as a one-way trip with Starship serving as the initial lunar base, but then we would need something else to bring astronauts back home.
I am not prone to conspiracy theories, but I have a feeling that this "choice" was done to appease SpaceX fans on one hand and to demonstrate how unrealistic Musk's plans are (with a hope that this will reflect on areas where SpaceX performs the best, therefore salvaging back some "territory" for darlings of best politicians money can buy, like Boeing.)
That said, perhaps SpaceX plans something entirely different, Starship only in name, that could serve the purpose. I don't see how. though.

while it seems very cool at first glance, the more I think about it the less sense starship makes as anything but a vanity project. It's an insane amount of additional and unnecessary weight to for instance go to the moon, all in the name of reusability. For Leo it wouldn't have a purpose, in space atmospheric engines are dead weight, and the additional fuel for all that extra mass requires even more fuel for the added mass of fuel, as a space transport it doesn't need all the added weight of stainless steel and atmospheric engines, and even it's first stage engine layout seems excessively complex like the n1. Tli is kinda useless without considering fuel to actually make a tli trajectory useful. Starship is massive and heavy. Despite a lot of talk regarding efficiencies of private industry, yada, yada, yada, private industry has the organic drag or requiring to make a profit on costs. Secondly, in-house expertise provides the host agency an in-house repository of expert knowledge that beer enables review of proposals, and monitoring of development by contractors. My guess as to why SLS still exists (other than the obvious political issues): Starship not only has not flown but is in very early development. Add to this the facts that, except for a mock up, we haven't even seen a fully constructed Starship, that somehow during tests Space X has blown up the last several very crudely constructed fuel tanks (water towers?) which are a key component of its Starship, and that we haven't even seen the untested booster formerly known as the BFR or have any concrete information as to its stage of development.  (I might add that many engineers suspect that the BFR design requiring more than 30 rocket engines is flawed and very risky and that Space X is making the same mistakes as the Russians did during their moon rocket development with a strong possibility of a similar result). At this point, it would seem that canceling a competing program would be premature, even foolish. If and when Space X succeeds in getting Starship into low earth orbit using the BFR as the booster, then the argument to cancel  SLS may begin to make sense for the reasons you discussed. A realist would say that the chance of a Starship orbital flight in anything like the projected time frame is only 50-50 at best.

Tim's excellent treatise is a great comparison between the "government way" and "private industry way".  Obviously the private sector is faster and cheaper because speed and costs are important if a profit is ever to be made.  And profits, after all, are what private industry is all about.  However, let us not forget that the private efforts of today would never have been possible without government initiation.  The private sector alone could never have achieved anything near the level of technology  we have today.  So many innovations developed by the private sector were started and funded by government.  The internet, for example, was an outgrowth of the military (which is just the government) ARPANET development, as was GPS and a huge host of other products.  Big government is often criticized for wastefulness, and rightly so, but innovations brought about by big government have been incredible.

The chain reaction of many object colliding with one another creates extreme threats for established orbital infrastures, not to mention space stations.  SUre the movie was over the top dramatic, but such an event is not impossible, as most objects launched into space is at least the size of a small car, if not a Van. Why? Simply put, by Dr. Jerry Pournelle: "Build more rockets. Fly more rockets." In more detail: you have to come at things from different angles in order to find the best solutions. If SpaceX fails, what do we do then? Oh, yeah: Blue Origin, Boeing, Lockheed-Martin, etc., etc., etc. It is, after all, rocket science . . . Which is notoriously difficult. Best to have as many options and companies involved. Hell, I still think that the VentureStar has some great concepts which might wind up being useful in the long run. The best for one situation is not the best for all situations. Just like water landings versus hard land landings: what are you bringing down, at what mass? And Obama was the worst (space [etc.]) president ever: the first ever to eliminate US access to space. Inexcusable. I agree with the title, the SLS needs to end. I wrote a term paper last year to explaining that the Falcon 9 / Heavy system is far superior to simplified SLS phases for the overwhelming majority of launches the two can handle, in terms of long-term program cost, date of readiness for flight, and environmental factors. By the time I was done I was asking that question myself, and the only reasons I came up with are that A) the smaller SLS phases are just stepping stones to a huge super-heavy launcher, and/or B) the Congressional requirement to use "existing partners" for parts supplies whenever possible is largely the result of some serious corruption.
If you're saying that SpaceX's Starship is also superior to the full SLS for most super-heavy lift missions, then SLS is starting to become a really, really expensive program for only a handful of circumstances that make it advantageous.

[disclaimer] I don't speak for the agency, and all opinions expressed herein are mine alone. TL;DR - This video is great.

I'm a NASA engineer at Kennedy working with the Artemis program...and other partners*. (Cool snippet with the ICPS in the SSPF high bay - I saw it too, along with the SN DreamChaser cargo module prototype). First, KUDOS for clarifying that NASA does not compete with SpaceX - that's so annoying. It's as ridiculous as saying that the Army competes with Boeing to build an Apache attack helicopter. Ugh; failure to launch. The best analogy of leveraging commercial partners (such as SpaceX) is like this: most normal people are inept at building cars from scratch in their garage (i.e. government), and it would similarly be a waste of time, money, and energy to do so in lieu of buying a Toyota or Ford. NASA is a partner rather than the driver, while SpaceX builds it how they know best. It's simply the model that the military (NRO included) has used for decades. NASA has to deal with constantly changing presidential administrations, members of Congress, governors, etc. It'd rather be off "sciencing" stuff - in the words of the legendary Mark Watney. It also learned very hard lessons about going fast and breaking things (Apollo 1, Challenger), and getting complacent (Columbia). As Administrator Bridenstine said, when NASA fails, the President of the United States has to get on the phone and on TV and explain to the whole world about an international tragedy. When we fail, America fails. That's a degree of accountability orders of magnitude greater than what private companies will ever have to deal with...and I didn't celebrate Demo-2 until the astronauts came through the hatch on Station, to drive home the point. Yes, you are 100% right about the army of contractors being a safety blanket...and it is just the price of doing business in this democracy. Going back to risk aversion, why is NASA skittish? I'll skit:
"Hello, World Health Organization and hi there, CDC...welcome to our Agencies Anonymous therapy session for survivors of real life Kobayashi Maru scenarios. Our name is NASA." :-)
That's why. Taxpayers are all too quick to grab pitchforks and pull funding when agencies make mistakes, or when we struggle to juggle plates while trying to walk on eggshells in a hurricane. For every finger pointed at NASA, there's four pointed back at ourselves. We got to the Moon in 8 years because they had 100,000 people building the VAB in less than 18 months, with no social media highlighting all the construction workers and wildlife killed in the process. Everyone should implore your congressman to support Artemis, and to pour money into that rather than swashbuckling with the Iranians and Chinese, and perhaps SLS would have already launched.
That out of the way, I am younger than the Shuttle generation and fully support the commercialization approach. We need their speed, their production capability, and their unique strengths for being profit-&-schedule driven. They cut corners where it makes sense, push the envelope regardless of what naysayers say, and are more insulated from political winds. On the other hand, we have deep pockets, institutional experience, and can get them to slow down periodically and think critically about outcomes. I personally think that NASA and the nation are better served by this synergy, as we focus more on what lies hidden in the cosmos, scientific discovery, navigating international cooperation, treaties, refining engineering principles, and freely sharing all of this body of knowledge with the public...that is why NASA does not compete with SpaceX. NASA will not get the budget it needs until the taxpayers and pols see a real return on investment, and companies like SpaceX provide us both good PR, consistency, speed, and lower prices. I have my own opinions on SLS, but suffice to say that I'm optimistic that this new private commercial sector is here to stay.
We are a team, with NASA the quarterback. Artemis is not practical without SpaceX, Blue Origin, Sierra Nevada, and many others....and they have no mission or funding without the initial government investment in R&D and scientific discovery. NASA has to first get to the Moon and study lunar regolith before Blue can make a business case to get over there to mine it. Starship is like the 787 Dreamliner, and SLS is the tried-and-true 737 (non-Max). Both have growing pains. You've summed up the situation nicely, and I endorse the content of this message.

Actually with a fixed fee, cost plus does provide incentive to contractors.  Its true that if they over run, then the government pays the extra.  However, financially, programs are measured by their Return on Sales (ROS), and having over budget costs with the same fee (profit), means the ROS (ie, basically the % profit) goes down.  Aerospace companies are ruthlessly evaluated for profit margins by Wall Street, and programs with low ROS destroy that margin.  No aerospace contractor wants to go over budget due to that.  They actually get higher ROS and the program finances better support the stock price when they come in under budget.  Everyone thinks going to fixed price contracting is better, but few realize that it will drive price up and often put smaller companies that can't account for the risk out of those types of contracts.  Both fixed and cost plus are useful, but for different purposes.  SLS would not be feasible for any aerospace company if it wasn't cost plus.

It's also called the dynamic model or triad model.  There is also the X model developed by JPL.  Boeing uses the Common method that engineers love.  Spacex uses a dynamic model.  The Common method is very safe because the final product is basically known before step 1 occurs.  It also tends to result in finished products with fewer flaws. It's also very expensive, inflexible, slow and tends to produce "last week's model" - outdated upon arrival.  Expensive because you don't work around a problem - you work through it - stick to the plan no matter what.  There is an old joke - if Boeing and NASA built a TV, it would be just like their rockets - massive and black and white.  In a Dynamic method,  each step plans the next step(s).  It requires that at the start, the final product be more conceptual than exact - because it will change.  It's fast, can be cheaper, and can respond to changes in the "problem" (the end goals), and produces cutting edge products.  It is also not as safe, prone to lots of prototyping, and has a great deal of untested tech.  The X model I don't know everything about - but it seems to be a mix of the other two models.  Which you might expect from JPL.  NASA probably uses something similar.  The triad method is something the government uses in everything from safety protocols to cleaning up super fund sites.  It is basically "try it, test, fix it, try it, test it, fix it...".  Each step directs the next.   Good video - after finishing it I realized you already know all the above.

You talk about showing your Iowa. I am in metro Detroit. I was an engineer. The last time I was looking for a job I interviewed with John Deere. At that time, their new system was set to use GPS guided equipment that could be set to drive itself. I know, that is standard now, it was new then. It would have also used satellite information to look at a field and indicate where more or less herbicide or fertilizer was needed. They wanted someone who could learn how to operate and demonstrate to sell the systems. So yes, they came to Detroit to interview engineers, especially people who were hands on. So the John Deere reference clicked LOUDLY with me. That and my parents came from SE Kansas, where we went for vacations virtually every summer. My mom's younger brother was a farmer (primarily soy beans, rotating with sorghum (cattle feed)). The uncle is retired but my cousin, his son, has his own farm and has taken over his father's when he retired. My favorite part of those vacations were time spent on the farm.

Cost of the space shuttle program: 196 billion. Cost to make one Saturn V: 1.23 billion. So they could have launched 196/1.23 about 160 Saturn V rockets taking 41 tons to the Moon on each launch. So the 165 possible launches of the Saturn V vs the 135 launches of the Space Shuttle would have meant 6x as much stuff delivered for the same money.

The SLS really shouldn't be a-- crewed launch vehicle, IMO, unless the side SRBs are removed and simply replaced with an upper stage for crew launches.

But as a heavy lift vehicle, the SLS advantage is in its ability to deploy very large and heavy structures and vehicles into orbit. The Starship will probably only be able deploy structures that are less than 9 meters in diameter (probably 8.1 meters in diameter max inside of the payload bay area and perhaps up to ten or 12 meters high at that maximum diameter).

The SLS, on the other hand, should be able to deploy pressurized habitats (maybe even expandable artificial gravity habitats) and spacecraft with diameters at least 8.4 meters in diameter and possibly as large as 12 meters in diameter. SLS payload heights could be as much as 20 meters tall within a ten meter in diameter fairing or up to 40 meters tall if simply deploying large pressurized modules without payload fairings.

In theory, you could replace the disposable RS-25 engines currently being developed for the SLS with the reusable version (AR-22) that was once being developed for Boeing's Phantom Express. That would mean that you could deploy a titanic reusable SLS spacecraft into orbit derived from the core stage and designed simply for crewed interplanetary missions. Operating out of LEO or NRHO, such a reusable spacecraft could be fueled by propellant depots and could transport large and massive payloads to the orbits of Mars, Venus, and possibly to the orbits of Mercury and Jupiter's moon Callisto. A single SLS core stage would have nearly 900 tonnes of propellant. But they could easily be utilized in pairs, on both sides of a transport module or cargo module, which would mean a vehicle with nearly 1800 tonnes of LOX/LH2 propellant with a specific impulse superior to that of the Starship.

>Starship cost of launch: 2 million dollars.

LOL. That's pure fantasy.
Starship is supposed to require around 4.5 million kilograms of propellant - 3.3 thousand tons for the first stage, 1.2 thousand tons for the second stage. I'm not sure about the exact weight proportions of methane to liquid oxygen, but let's assume it's 50/50.
1kg of liquid methane costs about $1.3 dollars. That's almost $3 million dollars. Liquid oxygen is much cheaper, but over 2 thousand tons are still going to cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. Pumping all of that fuel is also not going to be free and will require some personnel, machinery and electricity (pumping a giant rocket with thousands of tons of fuel will rack up a pretty hefty electricity bill).
So yeah, with $2 million dollars you will MAYBE be able to pump Starship's tanks like half-full.
Even they do achieve 100% reusability...what about maintenance? Safety checks? Spare parts?
This price is pure fantasy and a PR stunt, basic back of the envelope calculations demonstrate that this is simply impossible, even if you make magic assumptions that the rocket is fully reusable, requires zero maintenance, literally nothing ever breaks and needs to be replaced (not even a single screw), cleaned, checked or updated, is fully automated and gets refuelled and set up for launch with magic machines that run unsupervised for free and never break either...even with such fantasy assumptions, it still can't fly for $2 million.
Even the TARDIS from Doctor Who needs maintenance and repairs, so even if Elon Musk is secretly a Time Lord, Starship won't fly for $2 million bucks.

I really like the comparison of SpaceX's approach to rocket engineering with software engineering.

NASA's SLS is the result of meticulously designing and planning everything for years. Once the plan was ready, they chopped it up and told everyone "Do it like this, no deviations when avoidable, because if you change anything, we'll have to update all the plans we handed to the other companies as well".

SpaceX on the other hand is just "trying out" things and improving what needs to be improved on in a rapid schedule. If you don't know which of two options is better, try to find out by reason for a short time. If there's no clear winner, make an educated guess and just go with that. The key is to not lose time arguing what should be done. Save that time and thereby a lot of money by trying it now. If it happens to work out, good for you, if not, you probably have enough time to re-iterate; even better, if you were really fast, you might have enough time to switch over to the alternative altogether.

As a matter of fact, being a software developer, I can totally relate to both approaches. My company is too small to develop everything on our own. So we outsource some of the work to different companies, and it's a lot of work to keep everyone synchronized and informed about changes any company or we ourselves had to make to any communicated plans. On the other hand, when we develop something internally, we have already overthrown major parts of the code base, because we learned while maintaining our old code base. But the only reason we could do that, was because we could do it completely internally, and needn't inform anyone else about it. It's way easier to brief 4 people sitting around the same table, than writing an email to 14 external developers in 4 different external companies.

As for what approach I prefer, I think NASA should not develop a rocket at all. NASA should focus on raising funds for the scientific parts of those missions. Federal agencies are best when the return of invest is located in a far future or uncertain. Building space telescopes, conducting micro gravity experiments, and stuff like this which have no inherent commercial value is what NASA thrives at. Rockets on the other hand, or more precisely cheap launch pricing, bigger payload capacity, or TLI-capabilities, are of commercial interest already. Let "lightweight" businesses like SpaceX do the work to make whatever they do profitable. They will have enough investors who are trying to harness the economical advantage that cheap launch pricing has anyway. Facebook and Google are not interested in whether or not there's a black hole in the center of every galaxy, and whether or not lettuce can be grown in space. But putting satellites into orbit for 2 million instead of 200 million per launch, that's something Facebook and Google are interested in. Those projects will always be funded one way or another. Let SpaceX raise funds for humans, while NASA raises funds for humanity.

Great video...  I'd like to suggest one more contrast, that you have probably wrapped into SpaceX not having tons of subcontractors:   SpaceX is a raw-materials in, rockets out company.  Establishing themselves as an in-sourcing company early allowed for the rapid design changes and constant improvement.  But its also more risky, because they don't have other's buying their engines...  like Blue Origin.   One mentality allows one to focus on a few simple goals like being a low cost provider that is focused on getting to Mars, the other forces one to subvert their goals to whoever is paying the bills at the moment, and prioritizing squeezing dollars out of the government.   Perhaps this is an entire video of itself.   But it is a fundamental difference between SpaceX and every other mainstream rocket company in their performance categories.

Tim, how about making a video explaining/exploring the realities of a flight to, and landing on, the Moon vs landing on Mars?  People seem to talk about going to Mars like it's "just around the block" from the Moon.  There is a quite substantial difference in distance.  And unlike the Moon's fairly constant distance, the distance to Mars varies enormously throughout the 2-year cycle of our orbits, with the Sun coming between us!  Maybe you can illustrate that and other difficulties/challenges, and what solutions exist.  I mean, Elon seems set on building a colony on Mars.  Is he crazy?  Or does he have all the problems solved?  But just concentrate on the trip, maybe.  One hurdle at a time. :)  Is there a problem with 6 months of weightlessness going to Mars, and potentially another 6 months coming back to Earth right away in the event of not being able to land there?  Would manned flights be made in a single ship?  To such a remote destination as has never been attempted before...by a long shot...is it wise to go in just one ship?  What if you arrive in Mars orbit to find out you cannot land or return to Earth?  How long do you have to wait for rescue?  Can it help to send 2 to 10 ships simultaneously for mutual support?  After all, you can't do like Apollo 13 and just swing around Mars to come back to Earth.  And there are no "life boats" along the way.  If Starship is to go land on Mars, I would think you would first want to fly the heck out that thing in cislunar space with several 3-month flights to be damned sure it works flawlessly on long duration flights.  And land it in remote, desert locations on Earth, like Antarctica, Australian desert, New Mexico desert, and high plains of Peru or Chile...and refuel and takeoff back to orbit from those locations...although, Earth is a deeper gravity well.  What do you think, another video project for you?

In the words of Apollo 12's Alan Bean, "Outstanding, Tim!"  And Pete Conrad, "Fan-tastic!!"  :)  Man, let's get back on the Moon!  And when we do, mount stereo 4K video cameras on the inside and outside of the lander so that we can all experience the landing in VR goggles!  Now that would be awesome!  ...and easily do-able.  Man, that Pete Conrad was sure excited during the lunar landing.  But realize, he had the controls of the lunar lander in his hands, hovering over the Moon which he could see up close and personal in 3D...he was really there, and right where he was supposed to be. Starship is just a down-sized, more complicated version of Sea Dragon. We could have built Sea Dragon in 1969 instead of Apollo. It would have been so much cheaper, and the infrastructure requirements for it being so much less than the Saturn V, you couldn't have simply canceled it like Apollo. If for no other reason, it would have been too easy for a private company like Newport News to keep building them at a cost that would allow commercial payloads to fund the program. For the cost of the Apollo program, Sea Dragon could have put men on the Moon, built a mammoth space station, lifted enough fuel to said station to completely refuel a Sea Dragon upper stage, and put a significant base on Mars.


We could still do Sea Dragon. For the cost of $10B, you get eight development flights over fiver years. You don't need to build a launch facility. The rocket can be manufactured at one of eight shipwrights operating in NA.

The issue I have with SLS and Orion is primarily with the development time and costs.  The SLS is essentially a collection of old to very old parts that should have been cheap and quickly able to be assembled into a launch vehicle.  The rockets engine is usually the most problematic aspect of  a launch system development are in the SLS's case very old technology.  The RS-25 and SRB are late 1970s vintage, the RL-10s first flew in 1962 and the Orion Service Module engine is an AJ-10 that first flew in 1957.  It has taken over a decade at the cost of two nuclear powered aircraft carriers to assemble the SLS and develop an Apollo capsule on steroids. Someone or a number of people at Boeing and Lockheed Martin should being going to jail for wasting the tax payer's money so grievously.  Someone at NASA should be following them for letting them screw over the government so badly.

NASA has made significant contributions to science - few people appreciate just how valuable NASA is - not only to the USA, but the world as a whole. As a 12-year-old child, I remember listening (on the radio) to the 1969 moon landings. I was living in a remote town in central Africa (no television so we listened to the Voice of America on shortwave). I was awe-struck... not having visuals to complement the commentary forced one to imagine what was happening, and as it is with many 12-year-olds (who had read Jules Verne) I imagined the lander to be very sci-fi. That radio broadcast inspired my interest in space - and her I am, more than half a century later learning even more from Tim and his peers.

Big fan of SpaceX, however, SLS is also needed. SLS is going to be putting many "important" payloads up there long before Starship is going to. Starship is going to RUD a lot more times than it has already. It will almost certainly RUD once its "in use". At which point it'll get grounded for months whilst investigations and fixes take place. This will happen over and over again. They will learn lots, the final product will be amazing, but the reliability is going to take time due to the method of creation. SLS may still have issues, however, the probability of these issues is far lower. I think you're 2 years away from Starship reaching orbit. However, I think you're another 2 years until it's doing it reliably enough (and reliably reusable), then you're talking another 2 years before its reliably refuel-able making it capable of Lunar insertion. Couple that with the fact that either project may fail completely then you need to ensure focus is on both.

Anyone in engineering can tell you Cost+ vs Lump Sum is a no brainer. In Cost+, the client takes all the risk away from the supplier, and the suppliers profits are linearly correlated to how long they take and how many materials they waste. This is universally bad for the client AND the supplier (although supplier execs would argue with this point): they will usually pay more for a product delivered late and which was based on a lot of wastage and is never optimal. The supplier will have made a thing about 'doing things properly', i.e. not innovating even when there are clearer ways forwards that would take less time, reduce wastage and be cheaper, because to do that would reduce their end profit. Cost+ literally incentivises going poor engineering with no innovation. These types of arrangements normally last for the length of a typical industry framework (say 5-15 years) and then after that the client/supplier relationship is so bad that all the bridges get burnt, and the client has to get back to stage 1 on the thing they wanted done with a different supplier.

Lump sum is the opposite. The client enters an arrangement knowing that the only way for the supplier to make profit is for them to streamline the process and reduce wastage. Also, if there are issues in program, it's the supplier who has to deal with them. Yes - this typically means the supplier adds risk to their proposal fee (and hence usually makes them look more expensive at the outlay) - but the result is usually a better relationship. The customer gets what they wanted sooner, and in the future the supplier has worked out better ways of working and can do it cheaper next time, while still making a tidy profit. The only risk with lump sum is cowboy suppliers, who will deliver a 'product' but with very low quality because they saved money by cutting all the corners. Quality management is the client's best friend at this point and can usually prevent this from happening.

Lump sum is ALWAYS better for the client and supplier. Cost+ is absolutely terrible and the only people who like it are people who sit in board meetings at overinflated engineering companies who have confused the terms 'revenue' and 'profit', or suppliers who know they lack the appropriate staff and resources to do a better job. Source: I founded my own commercially successful engineering consultancy (and we only do things on Lump Sum following lots of stupid corporate bullsh*t at my previous Cost+ employer).

My rant: If we’re going to be serious about a long-term presence in space, then we definitely need multiple launch vehicles. But SLS is a backward project. It was sold as a way to reduce cost by reusing shuttle hardware, but now almost all of that hardware has been redesigned. It may as well have been built from a clean sheet. The shuttle was at least partly reusable, but SLS won’t be reusable at all. Yes, everyone laughed when Elon talked about building a reusable rocket. Now he has proven it is possible, but there is just too much inertia in the government bureaucracy to change SLS.
It’s like the government has spent 10 years and 20 billion dollars to build a new Conestoga wagon, while paying Henry Ford a fraction of that to build a factory for the Model T.
I’m glad that NASA has been able to help fund SpaceX’s development in the meantime. There is still a chance that Starship can fail, but SpaceX’s method minimizes that chance. The rocket will survive in some form, even if it looks completely different from the prototypes.
My prediction is that SLS only flies a handful of times. SpaceX and one other group will continue to the next round of Artemis funding. That other company may land on the moon, but so will SpaceX, and it will do so many more times and for far less cost.

As someone who has worked for aerospace firms as an engineer since 1980, I can tell you the contractors have problems. But that's only half the story, the other half is NASA. They are not lily white either. I've seen NASA stall on contracts and say it's the contractor's fault. They can't make decision in a timely manner. They have as many incompetent managers and engineers as the contractors do.  Additionally, I've seen them intentionally have contractors under bid jobs because they know congress would not pay the real projected price for the program. Case in point is the James Webb telescope. The initial cost projection was around $1B dollars, today the cost will be over $10B dollars. On that program, both the prime contractor and NASA are to blame for the overruns in cost and schedule. Because of all these realities, one can't expect to have fixed price contracts for these programs. If you did, the contractors would not bid on them.

I appreciate your comment at 28:14, that you can't just start building something and then change something in the plan, but this is one of the core reasons SLS is late and over budget. (For example: EFT-1 tested a heat shield that isn't on Artemis-1--the mission formerly known as EM-1--or any future Orion capsule.) Lots of design changes led to inefficiencies where the Contractors were willing to do and re-do and re-do because of the nature of their contract. United Launch Alliance act like they are getting paid to work on a rocket, not to launch one.
Also, as for hiring contractors, only to lay them off or reassign them, then try to bring them back later: That's exactly what they do and why NASA hires contractors. Rather than build a bunch of Orion heat shields, it looks like they are having the contractor build them one at a time, dismissing the team in between, and reconstituting it later to build the next at some point months or years down the road. I wouldn't be surprised if they do similar with the crews working on other critical components.
SpaceX, meanwhile, is doing Starship R&D largely out of their own profits (while still pricing services below their competitors) because their goal is not to earn government funding, but to build highly-capable, inexpensive to operate rockets. As Elon has noted, the hard part that they're working on is building a rocket _factory_, not just building a rocket.
SpaceX only gets paid if they deliver a product customers want. SpaceX's constraints are their objectives, not satisfying Congress' need to funnel money to their home districts, and due to that, it seems like there have been a number of questionable moves on the part of government to shore up the SLS (see Europa Clipper).
You noted that SpaceX were one of the three in the running for the Human Landing System (HLS), but it is worth highlighting that they are getting less than a quarter of what Blue Origin / Lockheed / Northrup are getting paid ($579M) for the first 10-months of development on a stripped-down version of Starship ($135M) that is for lunar-lander only operations (but still big enough to just about fit the third competitor from Dynetics' consortium ($253M) in the cargo bay). I guess that would make Starship-HLS the 4th version in addition to cargo, fuel, and crewed-reentry, and it seems likely the lunar-lander funds will be used to accelerate the development other 3 as well, but are probably only a fraction of the actual cost to develop the HLS version. Although in fairness, I should point out that NASA is already working with SpaceX on a separate project to develop in-orbit refueling, because NASA wants to use the technology and Starship relies on it. With Starship-HLS landing on the moon, SpaceX would have even more data to feed into the production of the other versions, along with time, money, and experience to perfect the Raptor and its mass-production, so it seems to be in SpaceX's interests to subsidize the development with their own money.

I am also pro space, but I still think it's perfectly reasonable to hate on the SLS rocket. The whole idea that NASA develops and operates it's own super heavy lift rocket may have made sense 10+ years ago. Back then you wouldn't find a private company targeting 100 tons to low earth orbit, moving terrestrial heavy industry to space or trips to Mars for their own purposes. Now that this exists, and especially since we are talking about US companies, the idea that NASA needs to have this capability of it's own is outdated. Another important skeleton in the SLS closet is that the technology doesn't really go anywhere new. NASA gets a big rocket and what is effectively a better crew and service module than during their last moon trip but how exactly will that let you do new science or push further into space? In order to make that happen you need resuability and in orbit refuling. The SLS does nothing to develop NASA hardware with these capabilities. SpaceX however is purposely looking to develop all these capabilities for their goal of reaching Mars and their commercial needs. And the same can be said for Blue Origin even though their plans are not yet finalised and what they have revealed seem more geared towards commercial use than accomplishing Bezos long term goal of moving or establishing heavy industry in space.

Now I'm not saying NASA don't need their own hardware in space or should just stop having things built to spec. I'm just saying there is no need for them to design all of it. Award a contract to SpaceX for an adaptor to the Super Heavy that can launch NASA hardware and possibly a propulsion stage that can be refuled in orbit, perform altitude control, offer multiple restarts and be controlled either from the ground or via an attached module and suddenly you have company building things custom for you that rely on hardware they were developing either way. In terms of cost savings you can write this off from money saved by not launching another 4 SLS rockets after the once that are planned. Going with the assumption that we will see horrible inflation that still leaves you with a budget of slightly less than ~$3000M after adjustments. So even if they end up finalising the SLS and use it for Artemis 1-4 it's hard to deny that this is a much better way to move forward past that point than to buy any further SLS launches or keep paying for enhancements on more cost+ contracts to companies who has no use of what they are building outside of said contracts. The thing is though that if NASA want's to do this they need to be ready to pay for it within the next 1-2 years. Because once SpaceX actually has a working prototype of their entire stack any adaptions to suit future NASA needs will be much more expensive as it may require unplanned redesign of existing parts. By the way I'm not saying that SpaceX should get exclusive rights to offer such capabilities, but let them make it now since it coincides with their plan then offer the same sum to Blue Origin or ULA if their hardware ever evolves towards similar capabilities. Just don't make another cost+ contract for it with a company that has no further use for such capabilities outside of government work.

I will fulfill your expectation by taking a side. SLS is old tech and too expensive, and as a taxpayer, I seriously dislike cost-plus contracting. Kill it.


But not right away, because we do need heavy lift, and Starship is not a done deal. They're going fast, and that makes me very happy, but Starship is undeniably a risky project. SpaceX will go at the pace that works for them, but we don't really know how quickly they will get to their milestones. Or if they will get there. If we kill SLS right now, and Starship is delayed or fails, we'll be out of luck.


There is a lot to excite me about Starship. Full reusablility! That gets my juices flowing. Cheap steel and cheap assembly: no clean rooms required (well, I dunno about the Raptor part). The hull, tanks and fittings can be assembled out in the open, exactly like a water tower. Raptor looks ready to go, very cool engine. SpaceX will have to solve orbital refueling, and that is amazing all by itself.


So what's playing in my head right now are two images.


One is Starship dropping to the moon to land next to little spidery low-cargo landers made by someone else. The cute little landers are unloading handsful of cargo. Starship unlimbers a winch and starts dropping tons. Am I amazed at the incongruity of that image? Yes, I am.


The other is an image of Starship plummeting through Earth's atmosphere on a return trip, hauling passengers who will attempt to survive a tail-first powered landing. Y'know, the idea of riding up on a rocket is terrifying enough. Starship's mostly free-fall descent followed by a burst of last-second flames to rapidly decelerate to touchdown is orders of magnitude more terrifying.


NASA will surely use Starship once it's working, but I bet no-one at NASA will agree to put astronauts on a landing Starship, either on the Moon or on Earth. No way, no how. They'll insist on using a capsule to get their people down to Earth and a lunar lander for the moon. I, for one, won't be able to blame them. Maybe after 500 landings with no accidents, we could get NASA interested in riding a rocket butt-first into hard objects. Maybe not even then.


There are many details to sort out in the Artemis program, including how Starship will be used for it (if it's ready), what particular roles will be assigned to particular spacecraft, how it will all come together. I have what I believe to be a somewhat unique opinion on this matter. I would say I lean more toward team Startship, but don't think I am just a fan boy. I am a software engineer and I understand the agile development cycle well, and I love it (even with it faults). I am also a government contractor and as Tim eluded to, there is so much inefficiency in gov't work, it's disheartening. I want to see a transition to gov't - corporate partnerships. I would love NASA to act as the liaison between congress and the corporate entities that would make up the aerospace industry. I would love to see everything owned and operated by corporations, with some funding, guidance, and regulations set by NASA. I personally believe the gov't should only be running the things that the public deems necessary but would not be profitable for a corporation to invest their capital into. Going to space isn't making anybody super rich just yet, and that's why I am grateful for even the SLS program. The success of the Commercial Crew Program is an excellent example of the direction I would love the industry to go. Invest in the most Aerospace industry and keep it honest and on track, but beyond that, let it do what it do.

I'm very skeptical that SpaceX will be launching Starship for even $100 million.

Ever since the launch of the Falcon 9, the cost to the customer has only gone up. A pre-flown booster today cost as much now as the first Falcon 9 (V1) rocket did brand new when they first started launching them 10 years ago. This is completely the opposite of what Elon has stated would happen in the past. He once talked about Falcon 9's costing as little as $5 million to launch. As it currently stands, the fairing alone cost $6 million. Now, from what I understand, there are planned price drops as of next year but they aren't anywhere near as significant as he had hinted years ago.

Now, I know that the current Falcon 9 V5 is a far more capable rocket compared to V1 but I have no doubt that the same improvements will be made to Starship. They will continue to improve upon the design and the rocket will become increasingly more capable. And like the Falcon 9, I just don't see the launch cost going down due to this. Even if Starship is 100% reusable. I imagine that by the time we see any chance of a price drop SpaceX will move onto their next big idea (EG a Mars base and/or new launch vehicle) and will require funding for that so prices will continue to remain relatively high.

I'm not trying to bash SpaceX here. I'm a huge fan, I watch all their launches and I'm extremely impressed with their innovation and how they've manage to totally shake up the rocket industry. But until we start seeing some actual, significant, savings that are passed onto the customer, I will continue to be skeptical. I just don't ever see Starship launching for $2million, let alone $100million (especially at the start). But I'll be more than happy to be proven wrong.

There's a mis-characterization of Agile design philosophy here. There are no steps on Agile, instead there are iterations over an MVP, minimum viable product, called sprints. Just a set of specifications for the desired result. It is not unusual for a sprint cycle to end without results. Also, I think Agile works on software because software's only cost is development time. If you have to rewrite an entire function in a library you are only investing time. On something like engineering space rockets it is rather dubious how effective it could be, if every test bed or prototype ends up being several billions of dollars on machining and materials, not just design. As seen, it is creating multiple piles of steel pretty fast. But who knows if it will deliver the promised Starship, it could very well not. That's a feature of Agile, you deliver the product that you got, it doesn't necessarily will be the product that you wanted, promised or imagined. It might not even work for the intended use.

I am completely dumbfounded.
I do not understand why the goal is to have a single rocket that will recreate the Apollo experience. How does a redo advance humanity?

We know that perching on low-earth orbit requires one set of engineering accomplishments. We can do that with several different systems that have been in use for years.

Falling to the moon with a one-shot exit strategy was proven effective 50 years ago. We can do that again.

It seems that the government is trying to "live through its children" and recreate its past glory by watching another generation do it again. I do not see any kind of technological "establishment" for a spacefaring future under that mentality. We know that the moon has rare earth minerals, rocket fuel and other opportunities that these systems will not be able to do anything with. The mission is go up - go there - fall - get up - come here - fall again. It makes no sense to me.

What I believe we need is a "STARSHIP." Well, actually, probably better named the "MOON SHUTTLE." Why not design a vehicle that can stay in orbit when static - and travel to and from the moon when dynamic missions are assigned? A smaller rocket would take a module [Soyuz?] up to either a Space Station [ISS reuse] or the "Moon Shuttle" directly. If to SS - design a vehicle to transfer from station to ship - or dock ship directly to station. [ Space Station Freedom reborn?] In static dock mode - the "Moon Shuttle" could function as an extension to the space station with equipment to do science while in orbit. Once astronauts perch, they could get the order to travel to the moon. Travel. Upon insertion into lunar orbit, they could enter a specially designed lander that could take ["fly"] them to the surface. This could evade the particulate issues of landing on the lunar surface - at a lunar base or landing strip. After time on body, astronauts could relaunch to rendezvous with the "Moon Shuttle" which would be in lunar orbit conducting scientific missions as they would have done if still in earth orbit. After docking - they would return to earth orbit, transfer to earth insertion vehicle - return to earth.

Current goals for the "gateway" would be met as part of the in-orbit mission set assigned to the "moon shuttle."
"Moon Shuttle" would not need to come back through the earth's atmosphere. The cost of transit would be reduced.
The cost of landing and return to lunar orbit from the moon would be reduced. They would only need to go to lunar orbit and not earth.
The cost of insertion to earth orbit and return would be reduced. We would not need new tech - we already have that capsule.

Capsule up to earth orbit and back to earth = ablative and 1 use as worst case - or dragon reuse as best case.
Capsule - or vehicle - to lunar surface could be fully reuse. We have history with ship [B-52} to sub-ship [X-15] systems. Just push the tech. Moon Shuttle to Lunar Lander.

What we do not have any experience with is creating an inter-geologic travel system. That development will need to come before we can go to Mars or anywhere else in the solar system. Move forward and develop it - develop our generation's own legacy.

Refueling in orbit is one of the technologies SpaceX is developing for the Starship vehicle.

Why can this NOT be done more cheaply, more safely, more advantageously, more progressively than our current idea ? We could even use the current tech to do it.

I have no doubt that SLS will be a capable vehicle when it's done, but there's no changing the fact that it's been a HUGE waste of resources. I fully appreciate that the following comment is a political statement, but it doesn't make me wrong: "Orange Rocket Bad" has never been a critique of the engineering, but about how Boeing is using it to milk the government and Congress is letting them get away with it. There's nothing "conservative" about SLS in actual practice.

The whole point of SLS was to be a shortcut. It was going to use hardware that industry already knew how to build and already had the facilities to produce, making it cheaper and faster than "starting from scratch." SLS was never intended to be some bleeding edge experimental vehicle - it was supposed to just work without much trouble, because all the R&D had already been done in the 1970s with STS/Shuttle. But as you describe in the video, they have thrown this one-and-only selling point of SLS completely out the window in favor of redesigning the core stage, which means that as a shortcut, SLS has already failed . . . . Unless the whole point of SLS was really to make work for a bunch of silver-haired, rent-seeking parasites in a space-industrial complex, in which case it's worked exactly as intended. But from a cost perspective, it's the worst of both worlds, because we're getting an expendable rocket that uses solids for probably the same money that it would have taken to just develop a superior all-new vehicle, if not more. Either Boeing have completely failed to meet their mandate, or they have willfully defrauded the American taxpayers and their representatives in Congress.

This design philosophy you've described, of making the perfect the enemy of the good and stretching out development timelines to avoid "risk," is only possible because Congress have forced taxpayers to bear the costs instead of the people actually responsible for making it succeed. SpaceX's expeditious and iterative design cycle is made necessary by the fact that they are paying for the thing with their own company's revenue, and THEIR best way to minimize risk is to get their vehicle working. They don't get their money back until they start using it.

Never mind comparing it to Starship, the SLS, with all the new tech development, experience etc that went into building it, still loses to the Saturn 5 in every category (except sticker price) and needs to reach block 1B to even catch up on the TLI cost. Plus, you can take an SLS's payload, put it into orbit using 3 falcon heavy launches, and save 605 million dollars. Alternatively, you could put 33 tonnes more then the SLS payload capacity into orbit using 2 expended FH launches at 575 million dollars less in cost. Then there's also the possibility that dragon XL (or something similar) expands the FH's payload to orbit capacity. And then Starship just handily mops the floor with every other rocket in every category.

So basically, the SLS loses to all the things it was compared to here. And I didn't even factor in the manufacturing speed of the falcon rockets and Starship's target of 2 ships per week. Ouch.

Contractors DO have incentive to finish Cost-Plus contacts on time and on budget. The profit (fee) is fixed. Finishing the contract on time and on cost (or early/under cost) increases the profit ratio.
For example: a contactor wins a contract worth $1 million, with 10% fee ($100k) and a duration of 1 year. If they complete on time and on budget, they earn $100k of profit on a year's worth of work. If they take 2 years and $2 million, they still earn $100k, but for 2 years of work, and have effectively cut their profit in half.

38:36 I think their are several factors. first the sls first stage is hydrogen so their is less fuel more specifically less oxidizer available. second the sls is the 2 stage to orbit as opposed to a 3 stage to orbit. 3 stage is more expensive but also more efficient since you are getting rid of more useless mass.


their is also an other factor to take into account in defense of the sls. It is not wise for to rely on a unique company to be able to provide a service that only they can provide because you risk that company fixing the prices for a service you absolutely need. I believe that is why nasa contracted 2 companies for the commercial crew programme, if only spacex or boeing where contracted they could fix the price they wanted. having sls means that spacex won't be the only lunar or mars transportation system available and thus prevent spacex from fixing exorbitant prices.

Given how much SpaceX has already changed their design of starship, and the fact that they are doing it while building and testing it, I wouldn't trust starship to launch anything anywhere, let alone crew to the moon. SpaceX's philosophy ever since they finished the falcon 9 is build first, design later, which may work with low risk endeavors like booster recovery, but will not work with something as consequential as starship. NASA, on the other hand, while their management right now is horrible, has actually designed and done the math on the SLS before building it. SpaceX has done a good job making large failures look small, they can't do that for long, until people realize how SpaceX is not being careful. While it may be while before NASA launches SLS, I guarantee that SLS will be safer, and more reliable than starship.

I'll give my 2 cents now, at the 5 min mark, and then after the entire video in case you change my mind.

Now,,,I wholeheartedly feel that NASA should have cancelled the SLS program after the 2nd extension. By that time, both Blue Origin and SpaceX had voiced their desires to build larger, more capable spacecraft. NASA should have begun the Commercial Space Partnership Initiative (I just came up with that, so feel free to tear it apart). With that initiative, NASA would have used the funds earmarked for SLS at that time, to provide grants to companies working on designs for large, heavy lift capability spacecraft. The NASA facilities being used by SLS at that time, would have then be made available for lease by such companies so that the workforce at those facilities wouldn't be left jobless. NASA should never have granted Boeing (or anyone else) a 3rd extension/funding increase once other viable entities were in the market. VERY poor mismanagement of that division of NASA. The administrator (who I actually liked) should have gone to Congress and outlined why the SLS should have been cancelled way back then, and that the funds should be instead used for this initiative. Imagine the launching capabilities we'd have had 2 years ago if companies like SpaceX and Blue Origin had been given that kind of funding 5 years ago!
